风景摄影：综合指南（+ 23 个专家提示）首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是达伦·罗斯。

大多数人没有意识到这一点，但捕捉广阔的远景或山脉的美丽图像并不是一件容易的事。风景摄影不仅仅是将相机对准美丽的物体并按下快门。这与技术、正确的装备以及了解如何充分利用您的设置有关。

幸运的是，只要掌握正确的提示、技巧和技巧，即使是初学者也能拍摄出令人惊叹的风景照片。这就是我在这篇文章中分享的内容：您想了解的有关风景摄影的所有内容，包括实际上保证为您拍摄出精彩照片的技术，无论您的经验水平如何。

继续阅读以发现：

  • 拍摄风景照的必备装备
  • 最好的风景摄影照明（以及您应该不惜一切代价避免的光线类型）
  • 完美的风景摄影设置
  • 专业人士使用的景观构图秘诀
  • 让你的风景照片变得独一无二的简单技巧
  • 多得多！

我还提供了大量示例照片；这样，您就可以看到实际的提示（并且您可以确信它们确实有效！）。

让我们开始吧。

最好的风景摄影装备

您可能认为您可以使用智能手机拍摄一些照片，但您并非完全错误。智能手机已经取得了长足的进步，它们的相机可以拍出一些精彩的照片。但是，假设您想要更多 - 更多控制、更多细节，以及创建能够准确反映您正在捕捉的场景的大照片的能力。这就是专业风景摄影设备发挥作用的地方。投资合适的装备可以让你的摄影效果从“还好”变成“令人惊叹”。

可互换镜头相机

如果您认真对待风景类型，您会想要选择一台好的风景摄影相机，例如全画幅数码单反相机或无反光镜型号。例如，佳能 EOS R5或 索尼 a7R IV将提供大量的百万像素（用于制作大型照片）以及稳定的低光功能（用于天文摄影）。如果您的预算紧张，请考虑较旧的全画幅 DSLR（例如佳能 6D或尼康 D800 ）。请记住，传感器越大越好，但传感器较小的 APS-C 或微型三分之四相机肯定可以完成任务。

广角镜头

一旦您获得了一台好的相机，您就会想要拥有一些高质量的风景摄影镜头。广角镜头是一个很好的起点。广角镜头的美妙之处在于它可以捕捉到更多您面前的场景。如果您最初只能买一个镜头，我通常建议使用广角到标准变焦镜头。对于那些刚刚开始摄影之旅的人来说，24-70mm f/4 镜头是一个不错的选择。

然而，不要只使用一个镜头就太舒服了。随着时间的推移，你会想要多元化。例如，70-200mm f/4 镜头可让您在不牺牲质量的情况下捕捉更亲密的风景场景。如果您正在寻找能够捕捉广阔远景的镜头，超广角 12-24mm f/4 镜头是完美的选择，尽管它可能有点贵。

三脚架

虽然我稍后会详细讨论相机设置，但重要的是要认识到大多数风景摄影都是在狭窄的光圈和光线较低的情况下进行的。当然可以实现曝光良好的照片，但通常只有将快门速度延长到 1/30 秒及以上才能实现。

如果你曾经尝试过以 1/30 秒的速度手持相机，你就会知道这真的很难；除非你的手非常稳定并且你的技术非常出色，否则你最终会得到无法使用的模糊图像。 （此外，即使是最稳定的摄影师也经常无法以一秒或更高的快门速度手持图像！）

这就是一个好的风景三脚架派上用场的地方。您可以使用它来稳定您的相机，并在 1 秒、5 秒甚至 30 秒的长时间曝光下保持照片清晰。是的，三脚架可能很昂贵，但最好的三脚架可以使用多年。将其视为对照片清晰度的投资！

顺便说一句：即使光线足够强，可以提供较快的快门速度，三脚架仍然很有用。它会迫使你放慢速度并更仔细地考虑你的构图。

一些过滤器

初学者常常忽视过滤器的重要性。在捕捉完美镜头的兴奋中，您很容易忘记有时您需要额外装备的帮助。圆偏振镜就是这样一种可以改变游戏规则的滤镜。当您拍摄水体时，它可以减少不必要的反射，并使秋季森林照片中的色彩更加流行。因此，它是您装备中的必备品。

中性密度 (ND) 滤镜是另一套非常有用的工具。这些滤镜减少了进入镜头的光线量，让您可以使用更长的快门速度。结果？无论是丝般光滑的水面还是纤细的云朵，都能拍出令人惊叹的长时间曝光照片。您可能还听说过分级中性密度滤光片。它们可能有用，但不是必需的；您可以使用高动态范围 (HDR) 技术实现类似的效果。

关键配件

装备不仅仅停留在相机和镜头上。如果您徒步穿越大自然寻找独一无二的镜头，您将需要一些额外的东西来让您的生活更轻松。舒适、宽敞的背包是您的首要必备品。相信我，当您徒步数小时寻找完美地点时，一切都会变得不同。

不要忘记额外的电池。想象一下天空变成了那些神奇的暮光色彩，而你的相机却快要死了——令人心碎。携带的电池数量一定要多于您认为需要的数量。存储卡也是如此；您不想在光线变得完美时就用完存储空间。

当我们谈论存储时，外部硬盘驱动器可以让您高枕无忧。那些美丽的风景，你辛苦了；无论发生什么情况，为他们提供支持都可以确保他们的安全。

风景摄影的最佳相机设置

当您在野外时，相机设置可以决定您的风景照片的成败。实现令人惊叹的拍摄不仅仅需要在正确的时间出现在正确的地点；还需要在正确的时间进行正确的拍摄。仔细调整设置以获得您预期的结果也很重要。这是我的建议：

以手动模式拍摄

如果您想创作既具有艺术​​感又充满细节的风景照片，那么我强烈建议您学习使用相机的手动模式设置。

您会看到，手动模式可让您独立处理三个曝光变量，每个变量对图像的影响不同：

  • 光圈可以使图像变亮或变暗，还可以增加或减少景深（即聚焦的图像量）。
  • 快门速度可以让您使图像变亮或变暗，还可以让您增加或减少图像中存在的运动模糊量
  • ISO可让您使图像变亮或变暗，但 ISO 越高，文件中出现的噪点（破坏细节的光线和颜色斑点）就越多

虽然我在下面更详细地讨论我的风景摄影设置建议，但重要的是要认识到，通过完全控制相机，您可以调整图像曝光，增加景深，防止噪点，并在以下位置添加艺术运动模糊效果：会。

虽然您始终可以使用光圈优先等半自动模式来拍摄风景，但根据我的经验，最好直接负责并处理您的设置！

使用窄光圈以获得最大景深

在风景摄影中，深景深几乎总是最佳选择。换句话说，您应该尽量让场景保持清晰。

为什么？从前到后清晰的风景提供了各种美丽的细节供眼睛探索 - 而且感觉更真实，就像观看者可以向前迈进并直接陷入场景中一样。

现在，最大化景深的最简单方法是选择小光圈设置（即大 f 值，例如 f/11 或 f/16）。光圈越小，景深越大，风景就越清晰。

选择较慢的快门速度和较低的 ISO

如果您曾因风景曝光不足而感到沮丧，那么您并不孤单。狭窄的光圈将为您提供所需的景深，但它也会减少到达相机传感器的光线，并阻止您的照片呈现出您所追求的清晰细节。

因此，请确保将窄光圈与慢快门速度配对。较慢的快门速度，尤其是 1/60 秒或更慢的快门速度，可以让更多的光线照射到传感器上。这补偿了通过狭窄光圈的有限光线。

但请记住，慢速快门需要稳定的三脚架。除非您希望您的风景像一幅抽象画，否则保持相机静止是没有商量余地的！

现在我们来谈谈ISO。提高 ISO 可以使图像变亮，但它是一把双刃剑。高 ISO 会引入噪点，这种颗粒状纹理是图像质量的死敌。噪声不仅会破坏细节，还会扰乱动态范围。那么外卖呢？保持较低的 ISO，如果需要增加曝光，请调整快门速度。

风景摄影技巧

准备好学习如何将风景拍摄从零变成英雄了吗？在本节中，我将提供有关如何使用光线、创作令人惊叹的构图等等的最佳技巧。

1. 提前勘察潜在位置

把风景摄影想象成一顿精心准备的饭菜。侦察是您在实际烹饪开始之前所做的准备工作。相信我，捕捉千载难逢的镜头的关键通常涉及大量的准备工作，就像在厨房一样。侦察的重要性怎么强调都不为过。有时，你只要出现就可以得到幸运的机会，但大多数时候，神奇的事情发生是因为你知道在哪里以及何时出现。

首先在网上甚至通过老式地形图研究潜在的位置。只要有可能，请提前访问您选择的地点。这可能是在实际拍摄前几天、几周甚至几个小时。查看景观的几何形状，并想象不同的元素如何融入框架中。照明是另一个需要考虑的重要方面。显示太阳轨迹的应用程序可能是无价的工具。了解光线落在哪里可以帮助您预测拍摄对象在不同照明条件下的外观。因此，无论是著名的旅游景点还是国家公园的未开发角落，都请给自己充足的时间去探索。您的作品集将会因此而感谢您。

2.寻找焦点

一旦掌握了设置，就可以开始考虑风景摄影构图（即场景中元素的排列）。

虽然构图可能是一个复杂的主题，但我可以提供一些基本指南，这些指南将对您的照片产生巨大的影响。

首先，几乎每一张精彩的风景照片都需要某种焦点——一个吸引眼球并吸引观众注意力的主要主题。

根据我的经验，一张没有焦点的风景照片最终看起来相当平淡和空洞。另外，它会让观看者的眼睛在图像中徘徊，无处休息。

请注意，焦点可以采取多种形式，包括：

  • 建筑物和构筑物（如上图所示）
  • 引人注目的树木
  • 巨石或岩层
  • 野生动物剪影
  • 一个人

然后，一旦确定了风景照片的焦点，请仔细考虑将其放置在画面中的位置。尝试超越传统的“居中”构图（主要拍摄对象静态地坐在镜头中间）。相反，尝试使用三分法，或者通过将焦点放在一边来实现极简主义构图。

3.添加令人惊叹的前景

风景摄影师初学者往往会找到美丽的场景，对准相机，然后按下快门按钮。

虽然最终的镜头看起来不错，但它们常常缺少一些强大的东西：

引人注目的前景，能够立即吸引观众的注意力并帮助他们进入场景。 （好的前景还可以使场景显得更加立体，这几乎总是一件好事！）

好的前景往往具有美丽的细节，例如花朵、树叶、流过溪流的水、闪闪发光的岩石或拍打沙滩的波浪。例如，下一张图片使用了一片开满鲜花的田野来增加前景的趣味：

4.不要忘记天空

在风光摄影中，你应该永远、永远、永远思考天空。

例如，晴朗的天空往往看起来平淡而毫无生气，而云彩和阳光的混合则提供了各种有趣的东西（以及日出和日落时爆炸性的色彩！）。

我喜欢在计划风景摄影郊游之前查看天气预报；这样，我就可以在阴天出行，最大限度地享受美丽的天空。

现在，我并不是说您永远无法在晴朗的日子里拍摄出精美的风景照片。但是，如果您面对的是晴朗的天空，请考虑等待，看看是否有几朵云——或者，如果您没有时间，请尝试将天空放置在场景中，使天空从属于场景的其余部分。图像的上三分之一，并将其​​与令人惊叹的前景形成对比。

另一方面，如果天空充满戏剧性、有趣的云层或色彩，那就让它发光吧。将地平线放在画面的底部三分之一处以强调天空，如下所示：

专业提示：如果您的天空看起来没有您想要的那么强烈，请考虑使用滤镜增强它们。 中性密度滤镜可让您使用长快门速度，像棉花糖一样拉伸云层，而渐变中性密度滤镜将帮助您平衡天空和前景曝光，以便您可以捕捉大量细节。

5.简化你的作品

您是否曾经看过一张风景照片并感到不知所措？也许它充满了元素——树木、岩石、动物等等。但有时，少即是多。专注于最小的元素可以增强照片的视觉效果。

首先扫描您的场景。你能拿走什么？不断问这个问题，直到只剩下使场景变得特别的核心元素。

现在，考虑在构图时重点关注形状和线条，而不是实际的拍摄对象。一棵树变成了一条垂直线，一个湖变成了一个平面。这种抽象可以帮助您从几何角度看待场景，从而更轻松地构建引人注目的镜头。

剩下的就是几乎感觉像是现代艺术作品的风景照片。这种简单性吸引了观众，引导他们的眼睛毫不费力地浏览图像。相信我，这种技术将为您带来一些最难忘的捕捉。

6.使用引导线增添活力

引导线是引导眼睛浏览图像的线条（通常朝向主要主题；见上文！）。

在风景摄影中，一两条好的引导线可能是平庸的快照和出色的图像之间的区别。

（为什么？引导线将观众吸引到照片中，而且它们还增加了很多深度！）

现在，引导线似乎很难找到，但实际上很常见。你只需要知道去哪里找！例如，您可以使用以下方法创建引导线：

  • 道路
  • 砂纹
  • 退去的波浪
  • 河流
  • 冰上的裂缝
  • 树叶
  • 倒下的原木

事实上，任何类似线条的东西都可以工作。诀窍是将线条放置在前景中。然后使用广角镜头并降低角度，使画面中的引导线显得很大并立即吸引观看者：

7. 纳入人为因素以扩大规模

捕捉广阔的风景通常是一个真正的挑战。很多时候，一张照片无法传达场景的宏伟，因为没有比例尺。这里有一个解决方法：包含一些人类视角的东西。

想一想。一条道路蜿蜒延伸至高耸山脉下的地平线，突然间，这些山峰成为引人注目的焦点。你看到那条路，你立刻就知道那些山是巨大的。

现在，想象一下在一棵令人敬畏的红杉旁边拍摄一个孤独的人物。瞬间，你不再只是在看一棵树；而是在看一棵树。你正在看着一座自然纪念碑。这个人成为了衡量这棵树是否宏伟的标杆。

当然，是否要加入人的因素完全取决于你！有些摄影师可能会认为这种方法混淆了自然场景的纯粹性，如果您有同样的感觉，那完全没问题。

此外，请记住平衡是关键。人的因素应该是补充，而不是分散。不要包含太多人性化的内容。相反，将人造元素融入构图中。如果做得好，效果绝对是惊人的。

8.充分利用颜色

风景摄影中的色彩思考不仅仅是捕捉美丽的日落。色彩管理可以决定照片的成败，影响观看者的情绪并引导他们的眼睛浏览构图。

那么，如何利用色彩来提升风景照片的品质呢？一种有效的方法是使用互补色。这些颜色在色轮上彼此相对。想想经典的蓝色和橙色组合。当您在晴朗的蓝天上拍摄阳光明媚的峡谷时，这些互补色可以形成鲜明的对比，为您的照片增添深度和兴奋感。

另一种方法涉及类似颜色，即色轮上相邻的颜色。这些可以使您的照片充满和谐感。想象一下在夕阳的金色光芒下斑驳的林地场景。黄色、橙色和红色的温暖色调可以营造出一种诱人、和平的氛围，吸引观众。

并且不要忽视颜色传达情绪的力量。颜色不仅仅是养眼的东西；它们可以作为一种情感语言。想象一下在山上捕捉一个有雾的早晨。蓝色和灰色的冷色调可能会唤起孤独或内省的感觉。

您还可以选择限制颜色以使特定元素脱颖而出。例如，蓝天映衬下的一片绿草在视觉上很有吸引力。但如果加上一朵鲜红色的郁金香，你就会突然成为一个引人注目的焦点。

最有经验的风景摄影师会对他们在镜头中包含或排除的颜色进行选择。意想不到的色彩可以吸引观众，但请记住，管理不善的色彩也会分散注意力。因此，下次构图时，请花点时间考虑一下色彩构成。您可能会对它产生的影响之大感到惊讶。

9.用长曝光技术捕捉运动

当大多数人想到风景时，他们会想到平静、安宁和被动的环境。然而，风景很少是完全静止的——如果你能传达这种运动，你就会为你的图像增添额外的戏剧性和情绪化。

（此外，您可以使用移动来创建引导线或产生引人注目的焦点。）

这就是你要做的：

首先，寻找运动，即使它很微妙。寻找树上的风、海滩上的波浪、溪流或瀑布上流过的水、飞翔的鸟儿或头顶上移动的云。将相机安装在三脚架上并构图。

其次，将快门速度延长至 1/30 秒或以上，然后设置曝光。请注意，不同的快门速度会给您带来截然不同的结果，因此最好在进行调整时拍摄多张照片。如果您在明亮的条件下工作，请考虑使用 ND 滤镜或偏光镜来减少照射到传感器的光线；这样，您可以进一步降低快门速度，而不必担心曝光过度。

请注意，风景摄影师只需尝试不同的快门速度即可实现各种不同的效果。例如，1/15 秒的镜头会模糊移动的水，但保留天空中的大量细节，如下所示：

而 30 秒的镜头会严重模糊水面并开始拉伸云层。

归根结底，与运动相关的工作非常有趣。只需拥抱这种效果，看看您能创造出什么！

10.黄金时段和蓝色时段拍照

黄金时段是日落之前和日出之后的时间，此时太阳低垂在天空中，产生美丽而温暖的光线。

黄金时段对于风景摄影来说是令人惊叹的。其一，阳光柔和地照亮了场景，强调了所有的小细节。看看金色的光芒如何完美地落在这些白雪覆盖的树木上：

黄金时段还提供了许多棉花糖色的天空，低太阳的角度在增强纹理的同时创造了有趣的阴影。

但黄金时段并不是一天中唯一适合风景摄影的时间。 蓝色时段（即日出之前和日落之后的时间）的光线也看起来令人惊叹：柔和、空灵、凉爽且神奇。 （另外，由于光线有限，蓝色时刻是进行长时间曝光风景拍摄的好时机！）

现在，您可能想知道：

我应该只在黄金时段和蓝色时段拍摄风景吗？或者其他时间也可以出去吗？

这是个好问题。根据我的经验，在阴天可以拍出美丽的风景照片，但你需要找到合适的拍摄对象，例如树叶、 森林和瀑布，我建议在你的构图中只包含很少的天空。

至于正午阳光下的风景摄影：尽可能避免。正午的阳光会投射出不讨人喜欢的阴影、褪色并产生大量令人不快的对比度。

11.拍摄亲密的风景照片

您看到的大多数风景照片都使用广角镜头。这是有充分理由的：广角镜头可以有效捕捉一览无余的远景。但有时候，真正的美在于细节。不要害怕近距离接触你的风景。这并不意味着您应该只使用微距镜头来突出森林地面上树叶的复杂性，尽管这是一种有效的方法。

长焦镜头也可以是您最好的朋友。这些镜头可让您将特定元素归零，例如有趣的岩层或一群生机勃勃的秋天树木。其结果可能是一幅感觉更亲密的图像，为观看者提供独特的视角。这里的风景充满了被忽视的宝藏，从山脉的图案到光线照射在树叶上的方式。打破广角拍摄的惯例，你可以在意想不到的地方发现美。

12. 测试风景照片创意

风景摄影非常受欢迎，正因为如此，有时会让人感觉每一张照片都被拍摄过，每一个角度都被探索过了。但如果您愿意跳出传统的框框，创意的可能性是无限的。例如，有意的相机移动可以产生令人愉悦的模糊效果，既梦幻又艺术。这并不是风景摄影中经常被推崇的晶莹剔透、超细节的照片，但抽象的结果本身就可以令人惊叹。

想要更多？考虑自由镜头。该技术涉及拆下镜头并将其固定在相机机身前面，稍微倾斜以创建独特的焦平面。这可能会增加意想不到的模糊和漏光，为熟悉的景观带来新鲜感。

也不要让自己局限于传统镜头。鱼眼镜头等特种镜头可以为您的拍摄带来全新的视角，以一种视觉上有趣的方式扭曲现实。关键是要放弃先入为主的观念。让您的创造力引领潮流。

13.不要害怕恶劣的天气

景观场景可能会因天气而发生巨大变化，因此您必须提前计划并仔细选择时间和地点。

正如我上面强调的，日出和日落时的部分云层覆盖会形成令人惊叹的天空（在蓝色时段部分云层覆盖看起来也很棒！）。但其他类型的天气也非常适合风景摄影，包括：

  • 多雾路段
  • 雨
  • 乌云密布，乌云密布
  • 雪
  • 彩虹

不幸的是，许多天气事件不会持续很长时间，因此时刻关注天气预报非常重要。如果您预计会出现雾、雪或暴风雨，请提前选择您的位置。雾和雪在森林场景中看起来很棒，而雨和暴风云可以极大地增强海滩和海洋的拍摄效果。

专业提示：恶劣的天气虽然非常上镜，但也可能很危险！务必告诉朋友或家人您计划去哪里，始终穿戴适当的防护装备，并为您的设备携带适当的防护装备。我建议使用防水相机盖，不过您可以随时使用改装的垃圾袋和一些橡皮筋（将其固定在镜头周围）。

14.拍摄夜间风景

夜间摄影就像步入一个全新的领域，虽然我无法在这里完全介绍它，但我可以为您提供足够的入门知识。

你看，夜景提供了天体奇观，但它们需要一些特殊的技能和装备。首先，也是最重要的，了解您的位置。当您只能使用手电筒照亮潜在的构图时，侦察就变得更加重要。

坚固的三脚架是夜间摄影的最佳朋友。长时间曝光对于捕捉弱光至关重要，任何相机抖动都会破坏拍摄效果。您可能会使用 20 秒或更长的快门速度，因此请确保您的三脚架能够胜任这项工作。

对天文摄影感兴趣？具有大光圈（例如 f/2.8）的广角镜头可以成为您套件中的宝贵补充。这种设置可以让您捕捉夜空，同时将星星的移动保持在最低限度。为此，您可能需要将 ISO 设置提高到 1600 左右或更高。但别担心，夜空的噪音是很宽容的。

15. 在降雪之后（或期间）拍摄

很少有场景能像白雪覆盖的风景那样迷人。世界仿佛静止了，裹上了柔软的白色毯子。然而，捕捉这些冬季仙境也面临着一系列挑战。首先，您的相机需要额外保养。如果拍摄时雪仍在下，请考虑为您的装备使用防雨罩。手边准备一块布来擦掉镜头上的积雪也能起到救星的作用。

保护好设备后，就该发挥创意了。白雪覆盖的背景可以带来戏剧性的对比。想象一下白色天空下一棵光秃秃的树的黑色轮廓。这里的关键是拥抱简单性。白雪覆盖的场景已经给人一种简约的感觉。不要弄乱它；让雪自己说话。

注意：快速的温度变化可能会导致镜头上形成凝结。为了避免在拍摄结束返回室内时出现此问题，请在进入温暖环境之前将相机密封在袋子或密封隔间中。将装备带入室内后，请等待几个小时再打开包；这样，您的相机就有时间适应室内温度。

16.不要忽视浅景深技术

深景深几乎是风景摄影的代名词。您通常希望从前景到地平线的所有事物都清晰对焦。但这里有一个转折点：使用浅景深可以给你的图像带来完全不同的、神奇的品质。将光圈打开到 f/2.8 或 f/4 可以让大量光线进入，并显着模糊背景。

关键是要专注于你的主题。假设您想要突出显示一块岩石或一片草地。调整你的注意力就可以了。然后，当您拍照时，背景会变成奶油色、梦幻般的模糊效果。

这不是典型的风景照片，这就是重点。您可以创建更亲密、更精美的外观，突出大景观中的小细节。

17. 进行黑白风景摄影

颜色当然有它的魅力。夕阳下的橙色或野花田的活力都令人惊叹不已。 Yet, there's something captivating about black-and-white landscape photography. With a focus on contrast, texture, and form, black-and-white photos strip away distractions. They direct your attention to the core of the scene.

In the old days, photographers started with black-and-white because that's all they had. So when you're shooting in monochrome, you're kind of paying homage to the roots of landscape photography. Plus, you don't have to decide right away whether you'll keep the photo in black-and-white. If you're shooting in RAW, which I highly recommend, you can make that choice later during post-processing.

That said, it's useful to consider black-and-white conversion while shooting. Look for elements that will pop in grayscale, such as stark contrasts or intricate textures, and really commit to a monochrome approach!

18. Think about the horizon line

This landscape photography tip is quick and easy:

Always pay attention to the horizon line, and do whatever you can to keep it straight .

A crooked horizon line looks incredibly amateurish, and while you can fix this in post-processing, you'll lose pixels along the edge of the frame – which will reduce your ability to print large and (even worse!) can cut off key compositional elements.

So make sure you get it right in-camera! Here, viewfinder gridlines can be helpful. Most cameras have these activated by default, but if you don't see them, head into the settings menu and switch them on.

And if you use the gridlines but you still struggle to keep things straight, you might consider purchasing a bubble level. You can attach one of these to your camera's hot shoe, and you can use it as a reference when setting up new compositions.

19. Combine light and shadow

You might have heard the saying that photography is the art of painting with light. Well, it's not just about the light; it's also about the shadows. Combining light and shadow in your landscape shots can result in some truly stunning images. The contrast between illuminated areas and dark shadows adds depth, creates mood, and draws the eye to key parts of the frame.

Waiting for the perfect interplay of light and shadow often requires patience. One of the best times to capture this is when the sky is overcast, and the sun is peeking through the clouds. When that ray of sunshine breaks through and lights up a portion of the landscape while leaving the rest in shadow, you've got yourself a golden opportunity.

Another scenario is during sunrise or sunset. Low-angle light naturally creates long shadows and can illuminate just the tops of hills and trees while leaving other areas dark. The contrasting elements give your photo a dynamic, three-dimensional feel that flat lighting just can't achieve.

So, the next time you're out with your camera and the lighting seems challenging, don't pack up. Stick around. Watch the light and shadow dance across the landscape. You might just find that the most captivating shots come when you blend both elements harmoniously.

20. Try HDR techniques

HDR photography sometimes gets a bad rap, largely because of overdone, unrealistic results. But this doesn't mean you should shy away from it. When you're faced with a challenging scene, such as a sunset over the ocean, your camera might not capture the full range of light. That's where HDR comes in handy. The idea is to take multiple shots at different exposure levels. One for the shadows, one for the midtones, and one for the highlights.

Once you've got your series of photos, the next step is blending them together. Software like Adobe Photoshop or Lightroom can merge these images into one. The result? A photo with details in both the darkest and brightest areas, much like how our eyes perceive the world.

But remember, subtlety is your friend. It's easy to go overboard with contrast and saturation sliders. Less is often more when it comes to HDR in landscape photography. Aim for a balanced, natural look to bring out the best in your photos.

21. Change your point of view

Are you looking to capture strikingly unique landscape images?

Then you've got to move past those basic “lookout” shots, where you point your camera at a beautiful scene, then snap a photo.

Instead, take a little more time with each landscape scene. In particular, look for an interesting angle or point of view, where you approach the composition from an interesting direction. You should have fun with this; try getting down low, finding a high vantage point, walking off to the left or the right, or even shooting from directly above (see the next tip!).

Often, these unconventional images are astonishingly powerful, in part because they show the landscape from a never-before-seen perspective.

It's important to bear in mind, however, that you should still pay careful attention to your gear and lighting. A unique perspective can add a lot to an image, but the best landscape shots combine well-chosen gear, great lighting, and a great perspective for a beautiful result.

22. Capture aerial landscape images

Taking your photography to the sky opens up a new world of possibilities. Aerial landscape photography has grown in popularity, thanks largely to the accessibility of drones. These nifty flying cameras allow you to capture views that were once only possible from helicopters or planes.

But capturing great aerial shots isn't as easy as simply sending a drone up and hitting the shutter button. It's an art form that has its own rules and challenges. Your composition skills are more important than ever. After all, from up high, you can see patterns and shapes that are invisible from ground level. Rivers look like veins, roads like stitches, and forests like broccoli!

When you're starting out with aerial photography, I recommend studying the work of other drone photographers. Look for elements that make their shots effective. Is it the angle? The lighting? The way they've framed a particular landscape feature? As you dissect these factors, you'll find it easier to replicate them in your own work.

Of course, safety and legality are paramount. Always abide by the rules governing drone use in your area. Most countries have regulations about where you can and can't fly, and some require a license. Make sure you're informed before taking off.

Once you're up there, the sky's the limit—literally. Whether you're capturing the intricate patterns of a cityscape or the sweeping vistas of a mountain range, aerial photography brings a fresh perspective to landscapes. With some practice and a good eye for composition, you'll be creating jaw-dropping images in no time.

23. Don't forget to edit your landscape photos

If you shoot digital—and most of us do these days—editing isn't optional; it's essential. Don't think of editing as cheating or as something that sullies the “purity” of your photos. Trust me, even the best photos can benefit from a little post-processing.

Imagine editing as the final brushstroke in your creative process. Sure, you can get great shots straight out of the camera, but they'll almost always look better with a bit of tweaking. Simple things like adjusting exposure, white balance, and contrast can make a world of difference. These basic tweaks aim to make the photo match what your eyes saw. That's what we call “getting it right in camera.”

But the fun doesn't stop there. Editing software like Adobe Lightroom or Photoshop offers tons of creative possibilities. Want to emphasize the golden hue of a sunset?你可以这么做。 Fancy adding a vignette to make your subject pop? It's all possible. And as you grow more confident, you can start playing with advanced techniques like dodging and burning. This helps to add a sense of depth and dimension to your landscapes.

In essence, editing allows you to achieve the photo you envisioned – or even to put your personal stamp on a photo. So don't skip this step. Even a few small adjustments can transform a good photo into a masterpiece.

Now that you've finished this article, you're ready to capture some stunning landscape photography! From choosing the right lens and filters to experimenting with settings and creative methods, these guidelines are designed to arm you with the knowledge you need to create captivating images.

So grab your camera, head out, and find a subject to shoot. See what you can create, and let your inner artist run wild!

如果您正在努力选择合适的旅行摄影装备，那么您来对地方了。

你看，新的旅行摄影师总是问我他们应该购买哪些设备。随着时间的推移，我开发了一套标准的物品，每个旅行射击者都必须拥有，从绝对的初学者到专业人士。

下面，我分享我的要点清单；它包含所有基础知识，包括相机、镜头和配件推荐。

（顺便说一句，在我们开始之前有一个简短的建议：购买足够的保险来覆盖您的相机和配件。事故和盗窃可能并且将会发生。做好准备！）

因此，如果您准备好组装一流的旅行摄影套件，那么让我们从最重要的装备开始吧：

1.相机一台

不用说，每个旅行摄影师都至少需要一台相机（如果您认真对待旅行摄影，我真的建议您携带两架：一台主体和一台备用）。

旅游摄影用什么相机最好？老实说，有很多不同的选择，其中很多都能够拍出很棒的图像，因此真正知道什么是正确的唯一方法是您考虑自己的拍摄偏好，然后进行一些认真的研究。

但我确实有一些建议。

其一，确保您的相机足够便携，可以随身携带到世界各地，同时提供足够强大的图像质量来制作令人惊叹的照片。这听起来似乎是一项艰巨的任务，但您可以找到入门级无反光镜相机、数码单反相机，甚至是傻瓜相机，它们体积小、重量轻，可以拍出很棒的照片（它们也不会花很多钱）。

当然，也有符合要求的专业级相机，但价格要高得多。专业旅行摄影师倾向于使用高端无反光镜和 DSLR 相机，价格从 1,500 美元到 5,000 美元左右。除了疯狂的低光功能和高百万像素数之外，这些相机的优点之一是（通常）坚固的防风雨密封。如果您打算在雨、雪、风沙或海浪中拍摄，防风雨密封非常有帮助。它甚至可能是必备功能。

如果您不确定特定的相机是否适合您，我强烈建议您在购买之前先租用。有很多很棒的在线租赁公司（您也可以在当地找到面对面的租赁公司）。拿起相机一三天，出去拍一些照片，看看你的想法。您最终可能会感到沮丧，也可能会坠入爱河 - 但几个小时后，您就会知道这台相机是否值得购买。

顺便说一句，当您准备购买时，请货比三家。不要忘记，您随时可以购买二手相机；这些价格只有一半，但通常状况良好。

2. 镜头

通常，相机只配备一个低质量镜头，或者它们可能“仅配备机身”，这意味着您需要单独购买镜头。

镜头确实有很大的不同，所以我建议您仔细考虑旅行摄影镜头的选择。例如，广角镜头会给你带来与长焦镜头完全不同的结果。大光圈镜头可以让你在非常低的光线下拍摄，尽管你会付出金钱、尺寸和重量的代价。

首先，您需要一个主力镜头，可用于大部分旅行摄影。它应该提供良好的焦距范围，应该相对较轻，并且应该提供良好的光学质量。我建议您考虑 24-70mm 镜头，它非常适合从风景到旅行肖像的各种拍摄。 （事实上​​，您只需购买 24-70mm 镜头即可；它们确实用途广泛！）

不过，如果您的预算允许，我建议您添加一个长焦镜头来补充您的主力镜头。例如，70-200mm 镜头非常适合拍摄更紧凑的风景、建筑细节，甚至大型（或驯服）野生动物。

随着时间的推移，您始终可以通过添加微距或定焦镜头来进一步建立您的镜头系列，但如果您可以从 24-70mm 镜头和 70-200mm 镜头开始，甚至只是 24-70mm 镜头，那么您将状态很好。

这是我每次旅行时都会携带的基本镜头清单：

  • 24-70mm f/2.8 变焦
  • 70-200mm f/2.8 变焦
  • 50mm f/1.2 定焦镜头
  • 100mm f/2.8 微距

3.三脚架

初学者旅行摄影师可能不喜欢购买三脚架——毕竟，它可能很贵，运输起来很麻烦，而且会减慢你的拍摄速度——但事情是这样的：

三脚架是您拥有的最宝贵的旅行摄影装备之一。事实上，如果让任何一位旅行摄影师说出他们最喜欢的配件，他们很可能会说三脚架。

是什么让三脚架如此特别？

其一，没有三脚架，就无法拍摄需要慢速快门的照片。防抖技术很棒，但你不能用IS来拍摄夜间超长曝光；尝试一下，您可能会得到一系列模糊的照片。

是的，三脚架确实会减慢你的速度，但这通常是一件好事。三脚架意味着您可以花更多的时间思考和创作，而不仅仅是拍照。

有很多令人惊叹的三脚架，您选择哪一种将取决于个人喜好、预算和重量承受能力。大多数旅行摄影师都会使用碳纤维三脚架，因为它们稳定且轻便，我建议您也这样做。

现在，当您查看三脚架时，您可能会注意到有很多便宜的选择 - 价格在 50 美元到 150 美元之间 - 您会想知道：为什么我买不到其中之一？

好吧，你可以，但它们通常重达一吨。您可能认为 7 磅听起来不是很多，但尝试一整天携带 7 磅三脚架（以及您的相机、镜头和配件），您会希望自己花更多的钱购买更轻的型号。

如果您找到一个重量不是一吨的廉价三脚架，它可能非常不稳定。您真的想依靠一些廉价且脆弱的东西来支撑您昂贵的相机吗？在我看来，您应该始终选择您能买得起的最好的三脚架。无论如何，它会持续很长时间，并且非常值得最初的投资。

4.相机包一个

三脚架可能是您拥有的最重要的旅行摄影配件，但相机包紧随其后，因此请确保您购买优质、耐用、舒适的产品。

您会发现，相机包经常被忽视，但它们不仅可以在运输过程中保证您的设备安全，而且还可以在您在目的地拍照时容纳您的设备。它们可以保护您珍贵的相机和镜头免受沙、雨和雪的影响，并确保您在步行或徒步旅行时保持舒适。

有很多相机包可供选择，它们在尺寸、耐用性、舒适度、配件和成本方面各不相同。您需要选择一个适合您的包，随着您变得更有经验，您可能需要为不同的场景购买不同的包。

例如，如果我徒步旅行或在荒野中外出，我会携带一个大而舒适的包，适合长途散步，并且里面有足够的空间存放设备、水等。另一方面，如果我在城市拍摄，我会带一个较小的包，甚至是单肩包，这样可以装更少的装备，但不会妨碍。

5. 存储卡

因此，您正站在令人惊叹的日落前，色彩在天空中旋转，就像艺术家的调色板一样。你的相机已经准备好了。但是请稍等，您的相机会显示一条警告，提示您的内存即将耗尽。当你疯狂地筛选照片，决定删除哪些照片以腾出空间时，那一刻的美丽就消失了。令人沮丧，不是吗？为了避免这种情况，请储备存储卡。其中很多。

你应该带多少？嗯，这要看情况。这是您的旅行长度、拍摄风格、相机的百万像素以及您正在考虑的存储卡容量之间的平衡行为。如果您喜欢长时间拍摄，或者喜欢连拍模式，那么您将需要大量存储空间，例如，大约 500 GB 甚至更多，以适应长途旅行。

不要只考虑数量；考虑您的数字宝藏的安全。稍后我将讨论外部硬盘驱动器，但在此之前，请投资购买优质的存储卡盒。这些漂亮的小容器可以保护您的卡片免受雨水、污垢和灰尘等元素的影响。这是一笔很小的投资，可以让你省去很多心痛。

6. 备用电池

切换话题，我们来谈谈相机的命脉：电池。正如您不会只携带一张存储卡去旅行一样，您也不应该没有备用电池。

当您无法预测自己是否会使用电源插座时，对额外电池的需求就变得更加紧迫。也许你在偏远的村庄，或者徒步穿越荒野；这不像你可以将充电器插入树上。

虽然原装电池可能价格昂贵，但第三方选项通常提供更经济实惠的替代方案，而不会在性能方面做出太大牺牲。在气候温暖且需要经常使用电源的地方，一个备用电源就足够了。但如果您要去气候较冷的地方，或者充电可能存在困难的地方，3-5 个备用电池会更合适，特别是如果您使用的是现代无反光镜相机，这些相机往往很耗电。

7. 外接硬盘

带着相机环游世界真是不可思议。然而，如果您的存储卡发生问题，那一刻的喜悦可能会变成恐慌。这就是外部硬盘驱动器充当您的安全网的地方。我强烈建议每个旅行者在他们的旅行包中都备一份。当您每天晚上回到住所时，您可以将当天的照片传输到硬盘上。这提供了双重安全网——保证您的拍摄安全并为第二天释放存储空间。

硬盘驱动器现在相当便宜，即使是具有 TB 存储空间的驱动器也不会花很多钱。专为耐用而设计的产品特别适合旅行。它们可以应对道路上的一些颠簸，而且大多数都是抗震的。您不想因为一点点摔倒而毁掉您无可替代的照片。

8.远程发布

三脚架是许多精彩镜头的基础。但让我们稍微扩展一下这个设置。远程发布可能不是您打包的第一件事，但是哦，它带来了不同。我们谈论的是太阳落山或在室内时清晰的照片。当然，您可以使用相机的内置计时器甚至智能手机来拍照。但远程释放消除了相机抖动的风险，相机抖动可能会毁掉原本完美的拍摄。

这款微型设备对于低光摄影特别有用，让您无需触摸即可触发相机。当您使用低速快门以获得完美曝光时，这一点至关重要。更重要的是，这些小工具并不是一项重大投资。基本型号的价格通常不到 20 美元。因此，如果您打算捕捉宁静的暮光或动态的城市灯光，请考虑在您的套件中添加远程释放。

9. 防雨罩

大自然是不可预测的！你身处一个美丽的地方，光线完美，然后——砰！雨滴开始落下。如果您不希望您的相机因意外天气而受损，那么防雨罩是您装备的明智补充。将其视为您相机的一份保险，保护您的投资免受水损坏。

在大多数情况下，基本的防雨罩应该可以解决问题。这些通常价格实惠且易于套在您的相机和镜头上。它们由尼龙或聚乙烯等防水材料制成，通常具有透明面板，因此您仍然可以看到相机的设置。但是，如果您发现自己处于必须即兴发挥的情况，用橡皮筋固定的垃圾袋也可以是一个临时解决方案。

这个装备并不华丽，但很有效。当您远离家乡，捕捉梦想中的场景时，实用性每次都会胜过魅力。

10. 清洁套件

换个话题，让我们讨论一下卫生问题——不是为了你，而是为了你的相机。无论您是徒步穿越亚马逊还是漫步巴黎街道，您的相机都面临风险。雨、灰尘、甚至雪等元素可能会将风景细节变成毁坏装备的噩梦。因此，正如您不会在没有个人洗漱用品的情况下外出一样，也不要忘记相机的清洁套件。

基本套件不必笨重。一个小袋可以容纳所有必需品：用于镜头的超细纤维布、用于清除讨厌灰尘的火箭吹风机以及用于伸入相机机身缝隙的小刷子。这些简单的工具可以成为你的救星，确保你的相机保持功能并且你的照片保持清晰。

11. 过滤器

您的相机捕捉光线，但您可以控制光线的质量。滤镜可以改变游戏规则，特别是对于捕捉不同场景的旅行摄影师来说。假设您正在拍摄一个被茂密树木包围的湖泊。偏光滤光镜可以最大程度地减少水面上的眩光，并使绿叶显得更加突出。它所造成的差异就像白天和黑夜一样。

中性密度滤光片是另一个关键配件。当您想要尝试长时间曝光拍摄时，这些功能非常有用。也许您在一条流动的河流附近，并且想要捕捉丝般光滑的水流效果。中性密度滤镜可让您以较慢的快门速度拍摄，而不会过度曝光图像。

最后但并非最不重要的一点是，让我们谈谈保护性过滤器，例如紫外线或透明过滤器。这些可能不会显着改变您的图像，但它们可以保护您宝贵的镜头免受划痕、污迹，甚至轻微跌落。我说更换滤镜比更换镜头容易得多，而且便宜得多。

旅行摄影必备装备：最后的话

购买你的第一台相机、镜头和配件可能是一个令人畏惧的前景。

但如果您仔细阅读此列表，进行研究并获得绝对必需品，那么您的套件将会很棒。随着时间的推移，您始终可以添加更多专业装备！

摄影中的快门速度：基本指南一文首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是达伦·罗斯。

什么是摄影中的快门速度？如何使用它来拍摄令人惊叹的照片？

快门速度是一个基本的摄影概念——每个初学者摄影师都必须掌握的概念。一旦掌握了如何使用快门速度，您就能够随心所欲地捕捉清晰的照片。您还可以准备捕捉有趣的艺术效果（例如慢速快门模糊）。

在本文中，我将带您了解所有快门速度基础知识，包括：

  • 快门速度的简单定义
  • 快门速度对图像的影响
  • 慢快门速度与快快门速度的不同（和重要性）
  • 如何使用不同的快门速度以获得出色的效果

因此，如果您准备好成为快门速度摄影专家，那么让我们开始吧！

什么是快门速度？

快门速度是相机拍照时相机快门打开的时间长度。

您按下快门按钮，快门打开预定的时间段（即快门速度），然后快门关闭，图像完成。

当快门打开时，光线照射到相机传感器；因此，快门速度越长，传感器接收到的光线就越多。这会产生多种影响，如下一节所述。

请注意，快门速度以秒（或几分之一秒）为单位测量。以下是一些常见的快门速度：

  • 10秒
  • 1秒
  • 1/10秒
  • 1/30秒
  • 1/60秒
  • 1/125秒
  • 1/250秒
  • 1/500秒
  • 1/1000秒
  • 1/1600秒
  • 1/2000秒

该列表以 10 秒的长快门速度开始，但快门速度越来越短，最后以闪电般的 1/2000 秒快门速度结束。

请注意，上面列出的快门速度测量当然并不全面。大多数数码单反相机和无反光镜相机都允许您选择 30 秒的快门速度，一直低至 1/4000 秒或 1/8000 秒，不过您也可以使用一种特殊模式（称为灯泡模式），让您保持快门按钮打开您想要的时间长度。

因此，虽然大多数相机提供几十种基本快门速度选项（快门速度预设，如果您愿意的话），但实际上您可以使用数千种可能的快门速度，所有这些都会使相机传感器暴露在略有不同的光线量下。合理？

快门速度如何影响您的照片

快门速度通过两个主要方式影响您的图像：

  1. 它增加和减少曝光（即图像亮度）
  2. 它增加和减少清晰度（即图像细节）

让我们依次看一下每一项。

快门速度增加并减少曝光

快门速度越长，到达相机传感器的光线就越多，图像就会变得越亮。

因此，如果您以 1/1000 秒的速度拍摄一棵树，然后将快门速度降低到 1 秒，您的第二张图像（快门速度较慢）将明显更亮。

这会产生重大后果。摄影的大部分内容都是为了实现场景的适当亮度或曝光，通过调整快门速度，您可以获得不同的结果。因此，快门速度是相机的三个曝光变量之一（另外两个是光圈和ISO ）。

因此，当您携带相机外出时，您需要调整快门速度以获得良好、平衡的曝光。具体细节取决于场景，但要注意高光溢出和阴影剪切。换句话说，确保曝光过度或曝光不足，以免丢失照片最亮或最暗部分的信息。

快门速度增加并降低清晰度

更快的快门速度冻结运动。较慢的快门速度模糊运动。

因此，如果您以 1/4000 秒的速度拍摄飞行中的鸟，每根羽毛都会很脆，甚至拍动的翅膀也是如此。但如果你以 1/15 秒的速度拍摄同一只鸟，它会变得难以辨认的模糊。

现在，冻结运动所需的快门速度将根据移动物体的速度而变化。空中飘浮的羽毛可能需要 1/200 秒的快门速度才能获得最大清晰度，而快速移动的汽车可能需要 1/2000 秒或更高。

快门速度太慢是照片模糊的主要原因之一，因此您应该密切注意快门速度值。始终确保它足够快以获得您想要的结果。

如何设置相机的快门速度

精确的快门速度机制因相机而异，但更改快门速度通常就像旋转拨盘一样简单（要了解所有细节，我建议您查看相机手册）。

请注意，调整快门速度的能力会根据相机模式而变化。

如果您使用自动模式，您的相机将为您选择快门速度，并且您进行更改的能力为零。

如果使用手动模式，则可以随意拨动快门速度（还可以独立选择光圈和ISO）。

如果您使用快门优先模式，您可以选择快门速度和 ISO，而您的相机将选择光圈以获得最佳曝光（基于对场景的评估）。

如果您使用光圈优先模式，您可以选择光圈和 ISO，而您的相机将选择快门速度以获得最佳曝光（同样，基于对场景的评估）。

不同的相机模式适用于不同的情况，因此不要只选择一种模式并坚持使用它；相反，学习根据您的摄影需求调整模式转盘。

如何选择完美的快门速度：一步一步

正在努力选择完美的快门速度吗？你不是一个人。

但是，虽然为您的拍摄情况选择最佳快门速度可能看起来很困难，但实际上很容易 - 一旦您掌握了窍门。这是我推荐的两步过程：

第 1 步：确定可以拍出清晰照片的最低快门速度

看看你的场景。问问自己：有任何物体在移动吗？如果是这样，我需要什么快门速度来冻结它们？

随着时间的推移，你会更好地确定尽可能低的快门速度，但一开始，这需要大量的试验和错误。以下是可帮助您入门的最低锐快门速度列表：

  • 水流：1/125s
  • 人行走：1/250s
  • 人/动物奔跑：1/500秒
  • 汽车行驶：1/1000s
  • 鸟儿飞翔：1/2000s

另请注意，如果您的场景为零运动，则不能简单地选择您喜欢的快门速度。如果您手持相机，那么您的手会颤抖，这会造成模糊 - 除非您的快门速度足够快。

可能的最低手持快门速度因人而异，而且还取决于您的镜头（较长的镜头会增加相机抖动）。得益于图像稳定技术，一些相机和镜头可以实现较慢的手持拍摄。但我建议短镜头的快门速度保持在 1/60 秒左右，长镜头的快门速度保持在 1/160 秒左右，至少在您完成一些测试之前是这样。

当然，如果您要拍摄没有运动的场景，您还有另一种选择：可以使用三脚架进行拍摄。假设您的三脚架很坚固，它可以让您将快门速度降低到您喜欢的最低速度（这就是您如何创建美丽的流动水效果，正如我在本文后面讨论的那样！）。

第 2 步：提高快门速度（或调整其他变量）以获得适当的曝光

此时，您应该知道拍摄清晰照片的最低快门速度。您不应低于此速度，但您始终可以高于此速度，具体取决于您的曝光需求。

如果您处于手动模式，请检查相机的曝光条（在取景器中）。如果场景曝光过度，请继续提高快门速度。

如果您处于快门优先模式，您的相机将自动选择光圈以获得良好的曝光。但只要您的相机继续选择您喜欢的光圈，请随意提高快门速度。

另一方面，如果根据相机的曝光条，场景曝光不足，则需要更改其他相机设置以获得正确的曝光。考虑扩大光圈 - 但如果不可能，则需要提高 ISO。

但是，请勿降低快门速度。提高噪点图像的 ISO 比最终出现不必要的模糊更好。

And that's it!回顾一下：首先确定拍摄清晰照片所需的最低快门速度，然后简单地调整以获得最佳曝光。

That way, you get a crisp photo – with a balanced exposure, too.

Slow shutter speed photography

The advice I've given above is perfect for situations where you want to freeze a moving subject.

But what if a sharp shot isn't your goal? What if, instead, you want to creatively blur your photo for a beautiful effect?

You see, blur isn't always bad; it can communicate motion, plus it can look truly breathtaking, as in this waterfall shot:

In deliberate motion-blur situations, you should set your camera to Manual mode, then dial in the exact shutter speed you're after.

At this point, you should check your camera's exposure bar and adjust the aperture and/or ISO for a good exposure.

Note that you definitely need a tripod for this type of long-exposure photography. Otherwise, the entire shot will blur!

Pro tip: If you're struggling to get a slow enough shutter speed without overexposing the image, consider using a neutral density filter , which blocks out light and is perfect for long exposure shooting . It's commonly used to create long-exposure images in bright conditions.

Alternatively, you can shoot in near darkness (either indoors or at night). That's how this subway image was captured:

What shutter speed is best? Basic recommendations

Now that you're familiar with the ins and outs of selecting a shutter speed, I'd like to share a few basic recommendations for selecting the right shutter speed. These recommendations won't always work, but they should certainly offer you a good starting point when adjusting your camera settings.

The best shutter speeds for landscape photography

Landscape photographers generally have two shutter-related goals:

  1. Get the image sharp from foreground to background
  2. Create artistic motion blur in moving water and clouds

Now, foreground-to-background sharpness refers to a deep depth of field . And while this isn't directly related to shutter speed, the longer the shutter speed, the easier it becomes to achieve a deep depth of field.

(Why? The depth of field is controlled by the aperture – and lengthier shutter speeds allow you to adjust the aperture without underexposing the scene.)

Plus, as I explained in a previous section, if you want artistic motion blur, you need to lengthen the shutter speed.

Bottom line: Landscape photography thrives on long exposures. Most landscape photographers shoot at 1s to 1/200s in bright daylight, and as the light falls, the shutter speeds slow. Many landscape shooters work at 1/30s to 30s (or more) around sunrise, sunset, and at night.

Such lengthy shutter speeds are only possible with a tripod. If you don't have a tripod, then it's often best to drop your shutter speed as low as you can go without creating camera shake (often around 1/60s or so).

The best shutter speeds for portrait photography

Portrait photographers can be pretty flexible when choosing shutter speeds. The key goal is to keep your shots sharp – by avoiding camera shake as well as motion blur – but because you can generally instruct your subject and work from a stable position, this shouldn't be too tough.

If you're shooting a stationary subject, feel free to drop your shutter speed to around 1/80s or so (though 1/200s is safer).

And if you're shooting a moving subject, such as a person dancing, I'd recommend working at 1/500s and beyond.

The best shutter speeds for wildlife and bird photography

Bird and wildlife photography generally involves capturing fast-moving subjects with long lenses.

Therefore, you should generally use the fastest shutter speed you can get away with. For slower-moving animals, 1/500s is a reasonable starting point (and you can go lower if the animal is completely stationary – just make sure you keep your lens on a tripod or handheld as stably as possible).

For fast-moving animals and birds, 1/1000s is the place to start. And when action is occurring, I'd really recommend pushing your shutter speed to 1/2000s and beyond.

The best shutter speeds for street photography

Street photographers tend to be less concerned with sharpness than other shooters, so your choice of shutter speed isn't nearly as important.

That said, if you're walking while shooting and/or photographing walking people, 1/250s is a safe starting point. If both you and your subject are stationary, then you can often shoot at 1/100s or slower (assuming you're using good handholding techniques and relatively short lenses).

Shutter speed in photography: final words

Now that you've finished this article, you're well-equipped to create some gorgeous photos.

So head out with your camera and test out different shutter speeds. Get familiar with your options. And try the two-step process I outlined above!

What is the best shutter speed?

Fast-moving subjects shot with long lenses require a short shutter speed (such as 1/250s or higher). But you can get sharp shots of stationary subjects shot with short lenses at 1/60s to 1/200s. And if you have a tripod, you can go even slower!

What is the shutter speed in a camera?

The shutter speed refers to the length of time the shutter is open when you press the shutter button. The longer the shutter is open, the more light that hits the sensor, and the brighter the image becomes.

What is a fast shutter speed?

Shutter speeds around 1/1000s and above are fast, while shutter speeds in the 1/100s to 1/1000s range are average, and shutter speeds from 1/100s on down are slow.

Is a higher shutter speed better?

A higher shutter speed helps guarantee a sharp photo. However, if your subject isn't moving, a high shutter speed can be overkill (and it will decrease the image exposure, which can be a problem). Also, a slower shutter speed can create artistic effects (such as blurry water).

What is a safe shutter speed?

A basic safe shutter speed is 1/250s, which will let you capture sharp shots of stationary and slow-moving subjects. But if you're photographing cars driving, birds in flight, or other fast action, you'll generally need to shoot at 1/1000s or above.

Below, I share everything you need to know to get started with manual focus. I offer step-by-step instructions on how to get great results, plus I explain when you definitely want to consider using manual focus (as well as when you should avoid manual focus, because it's not always such a good thing!).

Let's dive right in, starting with the basics:

What is manual focus?

Every image requires focusing, where the lens shifts its elements until you get sharpness in a particular spot. By default, most lenses do this automatically, which is known as autofocus . But you, as the photographer, can override your lens's autofocus mechanism and adjust focusing via a ring on the lens barrel.

That's manual focusing: where you take control, twist the lens's focus ring, and change the point of focus.

With manual focus, instead of letting your camera and lens decide where focusing will occur, you do it all yourself. But why is manual focus useful?它适合你吗？

Why is manual focusing important?

Modern autofocus technology is great, but there are certain situations where it struggles. It may lock focus on the wrong parts of a scene, and it may fail to lock focus completely.

Here are just a few scenarios where autofocus technology frequently gets things wrong:

  • When focusing in the dark
  • When focusing up close
  • When choosing between two dominant subjects
  • When focusing through foreground elements

Now, the efficacy of your camera and lens's AF technology can vary. Certain cameras offer autofocus algorithms that detect eyes and faces with outstanding accuracy, and certain lenses are lightning-fast, even in high-magnification scenarios.

Yet on the whole, most cameras and lenses will get it wrong on occasion, which is why manual focusing is so critical. If you know how to manual focus, you can switch away from autofocus when required, and you can still get the shot . So it's a valuable skill to have, and one that I recommend pretty much every photographer learn, no matter how useless they think manual focus may be.

How to manually focus: step by step

First, locate the focusing mode switch on your camera or lens. It will likely be labeled with “AF/MF,” where “AF” activates autofocus and “MF” activates manual focus. Like this:

Then switch your setup to “MF.”

(Note that certain lenses cannot focus manually; in such cases, you won't find any switch. Check your lens manual if you're unsure whether this is the case.)

Second, find the focus ring, which is often near the middle of the lens barrel (if you're using a prime lens) or near the end of the lens barrel (if you're using a zoom lens).

Look through your camera viewfinder, then twist the focus ring to one side.

You should immediately see the focus shift, as different areas of the scene go in and out of focus.

Now, when you're in a scenario where manual focusing is necessary (more on that in the next sections!), you'll need to simply turn the focus ring until your main subject comes into focus .

Sounds easy, right? It can be, though it's sometimes difficult to perceive focus through the camera viewfinder, so I do have a few tips for you:

  1. Switch over to your camera's Live View function , where you preview a live feed of your camera's sensor on the LCD. Magnify the image, then adjust focus until you see – while zoomed in! – perfect sharpness.
  2. Consider narrowing the aperture to give yourself a larger margin of error. If you shoot at f/2.8, you must get the focus right. If you shoot at f/8, however, you can stray slightly behind or in front of your subject without worry.
  3. After taking a manually focused image, check the result on the LCD. As with the live preview mentioned above, zoom in so you can be absolutely sure you got the point of sharpness you needed.

When should you use manual focus?

Autofocus technology is great, and I certainly don't recommend switching to manual focus all the time. Instead, you'll want to use it in certain scenarios, such as:

Macro and close-up photography

When you're shooting at high magnifications, lenses tend to hunt for focus – and when they do finally lock onto the subject, it's often in the wrong place.

That's why manual focus is supremely helpful; you can use it to gain focus more quickly and to set focus precisely where you want it.

In fact, I recommend photographers always use manual focus when doing macro photography with still subjects. It makes the process so much easier. (Manually focusing on moving macro subjects, such as insects, is iffier – it really depends on your equipment and your preferred methods of working, so feel free to try both manual focus and autofocus and see which works best.)

Low-light situations

Autofocus struggles in low-light scenarios , especially if you're shooting without any form of illumination (eg, in the desert at night, down a dark alley, etc.).

Your lens will hunt and never lock on anything, so manual focusing is a must.

Unfortunately, the darkness makes manual focusing difficult as well, so I recommend you use the Live View technique discussed above. Preview the shot via the LCD, zoom in, and make certain you've nailed focus before proceeding.

Note that different cameras vary in terms of their low-light focusing prowess. Try autofocus first, but if it doesn't work, switch over to manual focus for the rest of the night.

Shallow depth of field scenarios

Working with an ultra-wide aperture can be artistic, but this creative technique comes with a challenge: Due to the ultra-narrow window of sharpness, focusing must be precise .

In other words, if you don't focus very carefully, it's all too easy to miss the mark and accidentally focus slightly in front or behind your subject.

Now, there are times when autofocus can do a great job when working with a wide aperture. If you're photographing portraits and your camera offers an Eye AF option, you may not need to switch over to MF, and you can capture consistently sharp shots using your camera's AF mode.

But not all cameras offer Eye AF, and there are plenty of times when Eye AF won't work for your subject – which is why, when using a shallow depth of field, I strongly urge you to consider focusing manually.

That way, you can carefully set your point of focus right where you want it, and you can ensure that you absolutely nail the shot.

街头摄影

The pace of street photography can be electrifying. The quick movements, the unexpected moments – they're practically begging to be captured. You might think autofocus is the best approach, given the speed of the scene. And sure, autofocus can work well for street photography, and many experienced photographers do rely on it!

But don't be too quick to dismiss manual focusing for street photography. Some of the best street shooters in the world use a technique called zone focusing , where you dial in a relatively narrow aperture – this gives you a good depth-of-field window to work with – and then focus manually in advance.

What's great about this approach is that over time, you'll learn precisely where the window of focus exists. Then, when you spot that perfect subject or scene, you won't have to wrestle with focusing at all. You can simply get in position and snap the shot.

So rather than slowing you down, manual focus actually eliminates delays and can lead to some extraordinary captures. Remember, trusting manual focus in street photography isn't a limitation; it's an opportunity to master your craft in a new and rewarding way.

Creative effects

There's something truly wonderful about capturing a photograph that stands out in a crowd. One of the best ways to create breathtaking and original images is by experimenting with creative effects, such as intentional camera movement, deliberate misfocusing, and shoot-through techniques. But to get the best results, you invariably need to focus manually.

为什么？ Imagine you want to photograph a person seen through a veil of leaves and branches (that is, you want to use the shoot-through technique!). You want the person to be in focus while the foliage creates a natural frame with a blur effect. If you use autofocus, I can almost guarantee that your camera won't cooperate. Your lens will hunt back and forth until it sets focus on one of the branches, or it'll keep hunting and never lock onto a subject.

That's where manual focus comes to the rescue. With a careful adjustment of the focus ring, you can pinpoint exactly where you want the focus to lie, and you can nail your shot!

Or perhaps you want to experiment with abstract bokeh shots, where the entire image features nothing but out-of-focus blur. How do you tell your camera's autofocus to focus on, well, nothing ? You can't, but manual focus will allow you to take control and ensure that your point of focus goes exactly where you want it.

Bottom line: Whether you're playing with back-focus to create a unique blur effect or crafting abstract imagery, manual focus will give you the control you need to make your visions come to life.

Wide-angle photography

When shooting with a wide-angle lens, your subjects are often large objects shown on a small scale, such as trees, buildings, and other inanimate objects.

In such situations, because these objects occupy a small area of the frame, it can be hard to control your lens's autofocus; it might lock focus on an unwanted area of the image.

I tend to switch over to manual focus, though on certain cameras, you do have the option of magnifying the preview on the LCD and using the touchscreen to carefully select the right focus point.

Panorama photography

When shooting panoramas – which are created by stitching a set of photos together in post-production – consistency throughout the shots is key .

And that includes focusing consistency , where you focus on the exact same distance for each image. Otherwise, you'll get a disjointed result, and you'll fail to convince the viewer that they're looking at one continuous photograph.

That's where manual focus comes in handy. You can use it to pick your point of focus and leave the lens focusing in the same spot, no matter how the scene changes as you rotate your camera.

Hyperfocal distance photography

Whether you're capturing rolling hills or a bustling urban scene, achieving complete clarity throughout the frame is highly desirable – it'll add depth to the shot, plus it'll allow the viewer to appreciate each and every detail.

But capturing an image that's sharp from foreground to background can be a challenge. Your first step is to choose a narrow aperture, like f/11, which helps keep more of the scene in focus, but that's just part of the equation. Without a perfectly placed point of focus, even a narrow aperture won't keep the entire scene sharp, especially if your composition includes elements in the foreground.

That's where the hyperfocal distance comes into play. It's the specific point of focus that'll maximize the depth of field in your shot. (Note: Your camera doesn't come with a built-in hyperfocal distance calculator. When out in the field, you can use a rule of thumb, or you can find a tool that does the calculation for you.)

Once you've figured out where the hyperfocal distance lies, manually focus on that exact spot. Autofocus often won't cut it here, as it lacks the precision required for this technique. Once again, manual focus puts you in control, letting you set the lens exactly where it needs to be to capture a breathtaking landscape or cityscape in all its glory.

Low-contrast situations

Autofocus relies on contrast between the dark and light tones in an image. Contrast is what allows the autofocus to say, “Hey, here's a subject I should focus on.”

In low-contrast situations, such as a dark tree against a dark background or a white car against a snowy landscape, autofocus might just fail you. The lack of contrast can lead to continuous hunting by the AF system, which is not only annoying but also ineffective.

That's when you might want to switch to manual focus. By taking control of the focusing ring, you can achieve the sharpness you desire without the hunting. Just remember to switch back to autofocus when you move on to a different subject so that you're ready to quickly react to the next photographic opportunity!

Manual focus vs autofocus: When is manual focus bad?

Manual focus can be a powerful tool in your photography toolkit, but it's not always the best option.

If you're dealing with moving subjects or fast-paced scenarios, focusing manually may be completely fruitless. You might try working with your lens, but without the time to move the focus ring back and forth, check your focus on the LCD, and/or retake shots, you'll likely miss the moment.

Therefore, in genres such as sports photography, wildlife photography, bird photography, event photography, and car photography, autofocus is generally your friend. Your camera's autofocus system is designed to quickly lock onto subjects and keep them sharp, so in action scenarios, it's often the better choice.

Of course, there are always exceptions to the rule. If you're photographing an animal at night and autofocus won't lock onto your subject, you can consider manual focus. But as a rule of thumb, stick to autofocus when dealing with action. It's more reliable in those instances and can save you the frustration of missed shots!

Manual focus in photography: final words

Manual focus may have seemed daunting, but now that you've finished this article, you know it's easy – and that it can be super useful in the right scenario.

So practice focusing manually. Even if you struggle at first, you'll get better. And you'll be so glad you took the time to learn.

The post The Essential Guide to Low-Light Landscape Photography appeared first on Digital Photography School . It was authored by Natalie Denton (nee Johnson) .

Low-light landscape photography offers a unique challenge for photographers. On the one hand, a landscape lit by softer, subtler light can result in the kind of magical shots that go beyond more conventional photos. On the other hand, capturing these scenes requires a careful approach and a keen understanding of camera settings.

But don't fret! With the right guidance, even a beginner can create stunning images of dimly lit landscape scenes. And in this article, I'll explain:

  • How to consistently nail low-light exposures
  • How to keep your camera steady for rock-solid images
  • How to work with the light to create beautiful long exposures
  • How to select the perfect low-light landscape settings
  • 多得多！

So whether you're planning to shoot during dusk, dawn, or in the middle of a dark forest, let's dive right in.

The best settings for low-light landscape photography

Every image is unique, but certain settings are great starting points for shooting in low light. Over time, you'll develop your own preferences, but here's what I recommend when you're first entering the field:

RAW file format

If you've been doing landscape photography for a while, you're probably tired of hearing it, but RAW files will make such a difference to your shots. If you shoot in RAW, you can recover lost detail, and you can also make natural-looking adjustments to colors and tones.

Manual mode

I know it can seem daunting, but Manual mode really is ideal for landscape photography, especially low-light landscape photography. That's why I strongly recommend shooting in Manual. It'll allow you to tweak your settings constantly, and it'll also let you pinpoint the effects that each adjustment has on your image so you can experiment until you get a good result.

A narrow aperture

In general, it's a good idea to choose a narrow aperture like f/8 or f/16. This shouldn't change much from your standard well-lit landscape aperture setting – it'll keep the entire scene sharp, which is generally the goal. That said, if you're doing astrophotography, you'll want to choose an ultra-wide aperture such as f/2.8 so you can increase your shutter speed and prevent blur from the stars.

A low ISO

Set your ISO to its base value, usually ISO 100. This will minimize noise to ensure the highest-quality files for editing, sharing, and printing.

A long shutter speed

Since the aperture and the ISO will generally be relatively fixed, the shutter speed is the variable you can use to ensure an excellent overall exposure. Because you'll be working with limited light, expect your shutter speed to sit between 1/30s and 60s. Sometimes, you'll need to go even longer!

Essential low-light landscape imaging gear

While you don't need to rush out and spend thousands of dollars on new gear for shooting low-light landscapes, I do encourage you to spend some time thinking about the equipment you own and whether a few upgrades might improve your images. Here's what I recommend:

A full-frame camera

The best low-light landscape cameras contain a larger sensor. (Why? On average, larger sensors can take in more light per pixel, which results in cleaner images at higher ISOs as well as more expansive dynamic range capabilities.) Therefore, if you can, go full-frame.

That said, if you don't have a full-frame model, don't worry too much. Good shots are still possible with an APS-C or Four-Thirds camera; you just need to be more careful when raising your ISO or dealing with HDR scenes.

A fast wide-angle lens

Naturally, most landscape photographers shoot with wide-angle lenses; that way, they can incorporate the whole gorgeous scene into the shot.

And for low-light photography, I recommend you embrace that approach. A wide-angle prime will offer great image quality, will come cheap, and can offer exciting results. A wide-angle zoom, such as a 24-70mm, a 17-40mm, or a 16-35mm is also helpful, though more expensive, so think carefully before you buy.

Also make sure to check the lens's maximum aperture. For standard low-light landscape photography, an f/4 or even f/5.6 maximum aperture should be absolutely fine – but if you want to shoot stars at night, f/2.8 is a must-have.

A sturdy tripod

Low-light photography offers (unsurprisingly!) very little light to work with, so shutter speeds are long. If you're not careful, your images will end up ruined by camera shake. That's why a tripod is absolutely, one-hundred percent essential.

I'd recommend a relatively lightweight carbon fiber tripod if you can afford it, though make sure not to skimp on quality. There's nothing worse than buying a wobbly tripod, capturing hundreds of soft images, and only then realizing that you should've grabbed a good product all along.

A remote release

Even when shooting long exposure landscape photos with a tripod, you can still cause camera shake by hitting the shutter button.

That's where remote shutter releases come in handy; they let you trigger the shutter without ever touching the actual button. They're also pretty cheap, especially if you're willing to settle on a simple release.

You also have the option to use your camera's self-timer, but if you're capturing time-sensitive long exposures (such as a wave lapping at the shore), the self-timer becomes a major hindrance. Plus, using a remote release is far more convenient!

Tips to improve your low-light landscape shots

Now let's delve into some techniques to really level up your low-light images, starting with:

1. Spend some time scouting your location

Low-light landscape photography often requires shooting close to dawn or dusk. During these times, visibility can be quite limited, and the last thing you want is to be stumbling around in the dark. Therefore, it's essential to do some scouting in advance.

Visit the location during daylight hours, and walk around to get a feel for the terrain. Look for interesting compositions and visualize how the light might affect the scene. Think about the sun's position and how – if it'll be above the horizon during your planned photoshoot – its rays will create shadows and highlights across the landscape.

Consider taking some test shots during the day to help you visualize the final result. Also, familiarize yourself with the paths and surroundings so you can navigate safely when it's dark. If you plan to shoot around dusk, plot a clear and safe route back to your car or base location. You definitely don't want to get stranded alone with a bunch of heavy (and expensive) equipment!

Remember to consider seasonal and weather changes that might affect the accessibility of your chosen spot. Safety is paramount, so always ensure you have a well-planned scouting trip before your actual shoot.

2. 在黄金时段和蓝色时段拍摄

While low-light landscape photography offers plenty of fun, not all times of the day are equal – especially when it comes to the quality of the light .

The best time to shoot a low-light scene begins half an hour before sunset ( golden hour ), up to around a half hour or so after the sun has fallen below the horizon ( blue hour ).

Note: One common mistake many photographers make is leaving too soon after the sun sets. Sure, the golden hour is magical, but the moments that follow can be equally enchanting.

The faint light of the blue hour, just after sunset or before sunrise, offers a unique opportunity for creativity. Colors shift, and the landscape takes on a new dimension.

So while it may be tempting to pack up as the light dims, resist the urge. Be patient, stay a while, and explore the changing light. The blue hour can provide a serene and mystical quality to your photographs, which can be rather unattainable during brighter parts of the day!

3. Manually set your white balance

Some photographers like to leave their white balance on Auto and make tweaks in post-processing, and that's a perfectly valid method of shooting – assuming you're working in RAW.

Personally, however, I like getting my white balance right from the beginning. It means less time sitting in front of the computer, too.

I'd recommend setting your white balance manually (using your camera's custom white balance option, where you photograph off a gray card or neutral surface). You might also try dialing in different values, then capturing test shots until you get a result you like.

4. Use Live View (and your camera's electronic shutter, if possible)

Every time you take a photo with a DSLR, the mirror slaps up and the shutter moves – both of which can cause blur. (On a mirrorless camera, there is no mirror, of course, but the shutter is still a problem.)

To prevent blur, I recommend shooting with Live View. This flips the mirror up automatically so that it's out of the way when it comes time to take an image.

I also recommend shooting with an electronic shutter if your camera has one. Some cameras feature an electronic front-curtain shutter, whereas others offer truly electronic shutters; either type works. The point is to eliminate blur due to the shutter, known as shutter shock .

5. Don't be afraid to increase the ISO

As I emphasized above, a low ISO is generally best for low-light landscapes – but there are times when you'll want to boost the ISO.

Specifically, a high ISO is useful when you're shooting in near darkness and you want to keep your shutter speed below 30 seconds or so. That way, you can prevent the stars from blurring across the sky and produce a pin-sharp Milky Way image.

A high ISO is also helpful if you need to nail a certain shutter speed – for a creative blur effect, for instance – and you're struggling to get the right exposure.

Never go higher than necessary, though. The higher the ISO, the noisier the image will get. And while modern full-frame cameras can handle a lot of noise, keep it low when possible.

6. Watch for unwanted motion blur

I can't emphasize enough how important it is to keep your camera steady to avoid blur due to camera shake. But there's another type of blur that can creep into your images and detract from the final result.

I'm talking about the movement of elements within your frame, such as blowing grasses or trembling flowers. If your shutter speed is more than a fraction of a second, these elements will start to lose detail.

Now, motion blur isn't always bad. Sometimes, it can lend an ethereal effect in your image. But intense blur from wildly moving vegetation can take away from the overall scene. Instead of a serene or dramatic landscape, you end up with a chaotic mishmash that loses its details.

So what do you do if you're faced with moving elements that you'd prefer not to blur? Sometimes, it's a matter of patiently waiting for the wind to calm down. Other times, it may be best to revisit the location on a more favorable day. You can also try boosting the ISO or widening the aperture to allow for a faster shutter speed, though each settings adjustment will also negatively affect your image in other ways.

7. Incorporate a foreground element for added scale

I've talked lots about settings and light in low-light landscape shooting, but composition matters, too. You can start with the basics: the rule of thirds, minimalism, negative space, and leading lines.

But my best advice is to include some sort of foreground interest, like a rock, a log, or a river. Then let it catch the viewer's eye and lead them into the frame.

In fact, landscape photographers love foreground elements , especially when they're combined with wide-angle lenses. But make sure you have an interesting background element, too; the foreground technique is great, but only if the background element can offer a place for the viewer's eye to rest.

8. Take plenty of test shots (and check your exposure with the histogram)

Low-light landscape photography can be unpredictable, so I highly recommend you capture as many test shots as possible, carefully review the images you do take, and do quick but frequent checks of the histogram while shooting.

(In fact, if you shoot mirrorless, you might even be able to see a histogram in real-time; that way, you don't even need to fiddle around with exposure test shots!)

Remember, however: the histogram is a guide, not the king. You might notice the occasional tones pressing up against the bottom end of the graph, and that's okay. After all, low-light scenes are supposed to look dark sometimes. And you might notice the occasional tones pressing up against the top end of the graph, which is also okay; city lights will blow out, for instance, which often looks very cool, especially when featuring a starburst effect.

So pay careful attention to your histogram, and use it to ensure you've nailed your low-light shots. But don't obsess if the histogram doesn't show you a “perfect” curve.

9. Capture beautiful long-exposure images

I've touched on the importance of using long exposures in low-light situations throughout this article. But now let's delve a little deeper into how you can use this technique to your advantage.

A long-exposure technique can truly elevate your images. Think of moving water turned silky or fast-moving clouds stretched across the sky like cotton candy. These effects are achieved by extending your shutter speed, and they can add a breathtaking quality to your shots.

The key is to experiment and find the perfect shutter speed. Different speeds can add or remove texture from moving elements. Perhaps a 2s exposure renders a river too smooth, while a 1/10s exposure gives it just the right amount of motion. Don't be afraid to try different settings until you achieve the look you're after.

Also, consider the specific elements that will be affected by the long exposure and adjust your composition accordingly. Incorporating elements like streaking clouds can add dynamism and visual interest.

Taking the time to master long exposures in low light can open up a world of creative possibilities. With patience, practice, and a willingness to experiment, you'll find yourself capturing images that stand out from the crowd.

10. Bracket your exposures for maximum detail

Landscape photographers, including low-light landscape photographers, are faced with a unique problem:

Capturing tonal detail throughout a scene, even when the scene features a bright sky and a dark foreground, or bright city lights and dark buildings.

In other words, landscape photographers must learn to balance exposures so as to retain maximum detail. A histogram is ultra-helpful, as I mentioned in the last section – but what if you're not sure whether you got the result you wanted, even with the histogram? And even more concerning: What if a good result is impossible, simply because the difference because the brightest brights and the darkest darks in your photos are too significant?

That's where exposure bracketing comes in. It's a simple technique, but it's a huge deal for the committed landscape photographer. Here's how it works:

  1. Take a shot with a middle exposure value.
  2. Adjust your settings (generally the shutter speed) to slightly underexpose the scene, then take a shot.
  3. Adjust your settings (again, generally the shutter speed) to slightly overexpose the scene, then take a shot.

To some extent, you're creating backups, so that if you get the exposure slightly wrong, you still have a well-exposed image to fall back on. However, exposure bracketing can do more than that; you can actually blend several bracketed images together in Lightroom or Photoshop, taking the most detail from different parts of the images, so that the underexposed image contributes a beautiful sky, while the overexposed image contributes rich shadows. That way, you get the best of both worlds (and a stunning final result).合理？

And by the way: You can bracket as broadly as you like. Three bracketed images are pretty common (often with a margin of two stops), but you can also capture five, seven, nine, or more bracketed shots!

Low-light landscape photography tips: final words

Hopefully, you now feel much more confident – and you know exactly how to capture low-light landscape shots like a pro.

So head out into the field and practice (though make sure you bring a trusty tripod and a remote release along!).

Lighting can make or break a portrait. In my experience, it's often what turns an ordinary snapshot into a professional-looking image. Clamshell lighting is a technique that's simple yet powerful, and it can take your photography to the next level.

But what is clamshell lighting? And how can you master clamshell lighting setups for stunning results?

In this article, I explain the ins and outs of this simple – yet incredibly powerful – two-light portrait setup. From experimenting with different modifiers to playing with light positions and beyond, I'll explore all the details to help you master this wonderful lighting technique. By the time you're finished reading, you'll know how to create clamshell-lit portraits like a pro (no matter your lighting gear!).

So if you're ready to become a clamshell portrait master, then let's dive right in, starting with the basics:

What is clamshell lighting?

Clamshell lighting is a simple, two-light configuration: You place both lights facing your subject at a 45-degree angle, one angled up, one angled down. Note that your key light (ie, your primary, brighter light) should point 45 degrees downward, while your fill light should point 45 degrees upward. Your camera should sit between the two lights, facing your subject.

When viewed from the side, the two lights resemble an open clamshell (imagination may be required!):

A clamshell setup provides beautiful, soft light with faint shadows and glorious catchlights. Clamshell lighting works well on pretty much everyone; I'd say that it's flattering for men and women of all ages, so it's a great setup to have in your back pocket.

Note that clamshell lighting is just like butterfly lighting , except that you add the fill light below the subject (which eliminates any heavy shadows caused by the key light). So if you're already doing a butterfly setup, you can always add in a clamshell look at the end for some variation!

How to create a clamshell lighting setup: step-by-step process


Creating a clamshell lighting setup is simple, and as long as you have two working lights, you're practically guaranteed to pull it off. Here's what you do:

Step 1: Select your lights and modifiers

Clamshell lighting requires two light sources, and these can be strobes or continuous, modified or unmodified.

Personally, I'd recommend you use modifiers – these will help soften the light for a more flattering effect – and grabbing a pair of similarly sized softboxes is a great starting point.

That said, if you don't have modifiers or you prefer a harder look, then work with an unmodified light! If you really embrace the effect and sculpt it as needed, you may get a great result. Plus, it's your photoshoot!

Step 2: Position your key light

Grab your key light (ie, your main light source). The goal is to place it in front of your subject and slightly above; angle it down so it points directly at the subject's nose.

If you want a softer effect that features fast light falloff, bring the light in close to the subject's face. If you want a harder effect that lights the subject more broadly, move the light farther away.

Next, meter for your desired aperture (we'll use a hypothetical f/11) and take a test shot.

如果一切设置正确，您应该生成一个光线充足的图像，在拍摄对象的鼻子和下巴下方有很深的阴影。 （如果图像太暗，请随意调亮灯光，如果图像曝光过度，请执行相反的操作。）

第 3 步：添加补光灯

现在是时候添加第二盏灯了；将补光灯直接放置在主光下方，以 45 度角向上指向拍摄对象。

调整灯光的亮度，直到其位于主光下方两档。 （如果您想以 f/11 拍摄，您可以测量补光以获得 f/5.6 的结果。）然后进行第二次测试拍摄。

如果效果太强并且补光消除了阴影，请调低灯光功率。如果灯光效果不够，请将其打开。需要注意的主要问题是辅助光压倒了主光，因为这会导致从下方照亮的图像非常不美观。

第 4 步：拍摄翻盖图像！

此时，您应该有两个灯光共享相同的垂直空间，并且顶部的灯光应比底部的灯光亮大约两档。

站在灯光后面，从缝隙中拍摄。注意：如果没有太大的间隙，请升高和/或降低两个灯，直到有足够的空间在中间拍摄。为了安全起见，您可能需要再次抄表。

当然，一旦您拍摄了一两张照片，请检查相机的液晶显示屏是否存在曝光问题和其他问题。如果您有能力，我建议您将相机连接到笔记本电脑；这样，您就可以在大屏幕上立即查看图像。

这就是全部！翻盖式照明确实很容易实现，通过一些练习，您将能够在几分钟内运行两灯设置。

翻盖式照明与蝴蝶式照明

蝴蝶照明和翻盖照明经常一起讨论，但它们是两种截然不同的照明模式。

基本的蝴蝶照明设置仅使用一盏灯，位于主体上方并向下倾斜。由于没有补光，鼻子和下巴上的阴影仍然很重，从而产生更加戏剧性和强烈的效果。这种效果特别适合时尚摄影。

现在，让我们将其与翻盖照明进行比较。翻盖照明涉及在拍摄对象下方放置第二盏灯，以柔化阴影。这会产生更柔和、更舒缓的效果，因此经常出现在传统的爆头摄影或戏剧性少得多的应用中。

专业提示：如果您不确定想要的最终外观，可以随时从蝴蝶照明开始。尝试一下阴影和角度，然后如果您想要更柔和的东西，只需添加补光即可实现翻盖式外观。这样，您就可以轻松地尝试两种不同的照明风格。这是一种方便且富有创意的人像照明方法。

蛤壳式照明与伦勃朗照明

另一种值得考虑的经典照明技术？伦勃朗灯光。伦勃朗图案需要将光线放置在拍摄对象的侧面（通常大约 45 度），以在拍摄对象的脸颊上形成清晰的三角形光线。

由于伦勃朗光线将脸部的大部分区域覆盖在阴影中，因此伦勃朗光线以其黑暗和喜怒无常的品质而闻名。它是那些在图像中寻求戏剧性、戏剧风格的人的最爱。

那么翻盖式照明如何与伦勃朗相比呢？如果您想要拍摄更欢快、更细致的照片，翻盖式照明是更好的选择。通过将灯光放置在拍摄对象的上方和下方，您可以更均匀地照亮脸部并减少刺眼的阴影。这可以展现出更多的面部细节，让图像更加生动、更加平易近人。

简而言之，如果戏剧性和喜怒无常是您的目标，伦勃朗灯光可能是您的最佳选择。但如果要拍摄更令人振奋、更细致的肖像，翻盖式照明就可以满足要求。了解这些照明技术的细微差别将使您能够为每个独特的肖像拍摄选择正确的风格。两者都进行实验，看看您的想法！

翻盖摄影设置：一些快速提示

您知道如何捕捉基本的翻盖图像。但如何才能把镜头拍得更远呢？以下是我的一些重要提示，可以帮助您：

1. 尝试不同的修饰符

当您第一次开始使用翻盖式照明时，柔光箱可能是您最好的朋友。它们提供轻柔的触感，非常适合初学者。但当您变得更加舒适时，您可能会发现自己想要探索其他选择。这是一个绝妙的主意。

您有一对想要使用的条盒吗？大胆试试吧。想要使用美容盘作为主光并使用雨伞作为补光灯吗？当然。一个束光筒和一个小柔光箱怎么样？绝对地。使用你手头的东西。很快，您将能够像专业人士一样即兴发挥。

例如，美容盘可以创造出更硬朗的外观，可以为肖像增添戏剧性。它们的聚焦光可以突出纹理和细节。另一方面，雨伞确实可以柔化阴影。通过投射大量光线，它们使一切感觉更加分散和空灵。

通过测试不同的修改器，您将了解它们如何影响您的图像。所以不要害怕尝试新事物。请记住牢记翻盖照明的本质：让肖像闪闪发光的美丽、迷人的光芒。

2.尝试重新放置灯光

灯光位置在翻盖照明中很重要，甚至几英寸的调整也会显着改变最终图像。

将灯光移近拍摄对象，阴影会变得柔和并变得更加渐变，呈现出柔和细腻的外观。

将灯光移得离拍摄对象更远，阴影就会变硬、变得更清晰。这可以为图像增添深度感和戏剧性。

但这不仅仅是距离的问题。您可以将主光移得更高以创建更长的阴影，或降低主光以创建更短的阴影。您可以对补光灯执行相同的操作。

只是要小心不要太过分。我在最初的分步部分中讨论的 45 度位置旨在看起来更讨人喜欢。调整位置固然很棒，但不要忽视你最初的目标！

3.添加更多灯光

一旦你正确设置了翻盖照明，你可能会认为你已经完成了。但您还可以采取更多措施来增强场景并创建引人注目的图像。

例如，您可以在拍摄对象后面（一侧或两侧）添加边缘光，以在头部周围创建精致的光线。此效果将帮助您的主题从背景中脱颖而出，并使图像更具活力。

头发灯可以增加照片的深度。它位于拍摄对象的上方和后方，巧妙地照射在头发上，将其与背景分开。

也不要犹豫尝试背景灯。在拍摄对象后面放置一盏灯（指向背景）可以创造出美丽的锥形光，增加额外的深度。许多摄影师将光线充足的拍摄对象与光线充足的背景结合在一起！

底线：通过添加这些额外的灯光，您可以给自己更多的创作自由，并在翻盖式照明设置中打开一个充满可能性的世界。

4. 转换为黑白

翻盖式照明可产生精美的图像，无论是彩色还是黑白，都看起来令人惊叹。将照片转换为黑白将强调阴影和高光的相互作用，同时可能为照片添加三维层。

如果您以 RAW 格式拍摄（我强烈建议您这样做），您可以灵活地使用相机的单色模式进行拍摄，并且在需要时仍可以转换回彩色模式。或者，您可以从彩色开始，然后再转换为黑白。

黑白转换可以使脸部特征以独特的方式突出。它可能会凸显纹理、强调对比，甚至创造一种颜色无法捕捉到的情绪。通过尝试这种转换，您可以在单个照明设置中探索一系列视觉表达，这始终是一个好主意！

5.观察聚光灯

聚光灯是主体眼睛中的神奇光点，是由光源反射产生的。它给眼睛带来活力；如果没有聚光灯，眼睛以及整个肖像就会显得平淡而毫无生气。

因此，务必确保您的翻盖照片包含聚光灯！如果没有聚光灯，您可能需要要求拍摄对象调整头部角度，或者可能需要对灯光进行轻微调整。请务必在相机液晶显示屏上查看每个测试镜头，以确保聚光灯符合您的要求。

请注意，对于翻盖照明，由于它涉及两个灯而不是一个，因此您可能会注意到双聚光灯。这是一些摄影师喜欢的功能，而另一些摄影师则不太热衷。

如果您不喜欢底部聚光灯，请不要担心！它始终可以在后处理过程中克隆出来。

翻盖照明示例

摄影中的负空间：基本指南首先出现在数码摄影学校上。它的作者是桑德拉·鲁西。

什么是摄影中的负空间？如何将其用于美丽的构图？

负空间这个词可能听起来很奇怪，但它实际上是几乎所有伟大图像的重要组成部分。事实上，如果你想创作出绚丽的照片，就必须掌握负空间；这样，您就可以拍出平衡、和谐、引人注目的照片。 （您还可以捕捉极简主义的构图，正如我在下面讨论的那样。）

在本文中，我将解释您需要了解的有关负空间的所有信息，包括：

  • 负空间实际上是什么
  • 为什么负空间很重要
  • 无论您拍摄风景、肖像、街景还是建筑，在图像中使用负空间的简单提示和技巧

准备好成为作曲大师了吗？那么我们就开始吧。

什么是负空间？

负空间是指构图中空旷、乏味或无趣的区域。这就是为什么负空间也被称为空白；这是什么都没有真正发生的地方。

看看下一张图片，其中有雾的天空和空旷的水面充当负空间：

在摄影中，负空间通常由某些元素组成：

  • 水
  • Sky
  • 墙壁
  • Sand

请注意，所有这些元素都很容易淡入背景，这就是为什么它们会产生如此大的负空间。空旷的天空并不引人注目，就像空白的白墙、一片空旷的沙子等等一样。

现在，有些照片充满了负空间。这些构图通常非常抽象，例如一片空旷的蓝天，或者向各个方向延伸的沙丘。这种以负空间为中心的构图也可以是简约的，只有一个引人注目的元素被空虚包围。

然而，其他照片则具有大量非负空间，也称为正空间：

正空间与负空间

正空间与负空间完全相反。负空间拒绝眼球，而正空间则抢尽风头。你看，正空间是照片中包含感兴趣元素的区域，包含主要主题的区域，观看者眼睛首先看到的区域。

在下面的照片中，有大量的正空间，但负空间很少。旗帜、建筑物和树木都充当积极的空间。由于其有趣的排列和纹理，甚至云也提供了一些积极的空间。最大的负空间是天空，它只占镜头的一小部分。

现在，正空间可以是任何东西，但以下是一些常见的例子：

  • Faces
  • People
  • 建筑物
  • 鸟类
  • 野生动物
  • 山脉

那么正空间和负空间哪个更好？

两者都不。

在摄影中，目标是将两种类型的空间结合起来，创造出平衡的构图。是的，你想要负空间，但你也想要正空间。这样您才能获得始终如一的令人惊叹的照片！

负空间和极简主义

从技术上讲，负空间几乎存在于每张图像中，即使构图是混乱的、混乱的或压倒性的。但当您想到负空间时，您可能会将其与极简主义联系起来。为什么？

摄影中的极简主义非常强调负空间以创造宁静的效果。此类图像使用大量负空间，为观看者提供充足的呼吸空间并专注于主题。

想象一下田野中一棵孤独的树或一个孤独的人，周围都是空虚的。它构成了一个引人注目的构图，这主要归功于负空间的力量！

但我想强调一个要点：并非所有带有负空间的图像都是简约的。极简主义以独特的方式使用负空间，你可以通过采取极简主义的方法来获得惊人的结果，但你不必这样做。您始终可以通过正负空间的平衡组合来构图，以获得不同的效果。

负空间摄影的最佳类型

负空间并不局限于单一类型。事实上，您可以将这个概念应用于各种类型的摄影。

以风景拍摄为例。广阔的天空、海滩、山脉和沙漠常常需要大量使用负空间。这使得主要拍摄对象（例如山或树）真正脱颖而出。

旅行摄影也受益于负空间。想象一条路延伸穿过一片空旷的风景，或者一个人站在湖边；结果既有意义又引人注目。

即使某些形式的街头摄影也可以在大量负​​空间的情况下看起来很棒。一个孤独的身影穿过开阔的广场，可以充分表达城市生活和孤独。

另一方面，人像摄影、事件摄影、纪实摄影和体育摄影通常更注重积极的空间。这里的目的是传达有关人、环境或故事的信息，而积极的空间通常会传达更多细节。

但不要让它限制你！如果您有灵感拍摄带有大量负空间的纪实图像，那就去做吧。创造力无国界，尝试新方法总是令人耳目一新。

我上面分享的流派和想法只是建议。摄影之美在于个人的诠释和实验。深入研究不同的主题，看看负空间如何增强您的风格。

负空间摄影技巧和窍门

希望您现在已经准备好拍摄一些属于您自己的负空间图像。为此，以下是我最喜欢的处理负空间的技巧和技巧：

1.让场景决定负空间和正空间的组合

每个场景都有不同的负空间与正空间的比例。

虽然作为摄影师，您可以放大、改变视角和裁剪以强调场景的某些部分，但您需要保持灵活性；你需要能够拥抱一个充满负空间的场景，就像你拥抱一个充满正空间的场景一样。

因此，不要试图将场景强行推向某个方向。相反，问问自己：场景已经是什么样子了？并利用你所拥有的。

例如，几年前，我站在一个受欢迎的瞭望台，观察加拿大东部大西洋上的一块标志性岩石。当时是清晨，薄雾笼罩着这座令人印象深刻的建筑的大部分。站在我旁边的女士转身对我说：“太伤心了，我们今天开车经过，我想拍一张珀塞岩石的照片。但由于大雾，看来这是不可能的。”

她离开了，对自己没有得到注射感到失望。但我留了下来，站了很长时间，审视着雾气以及它像一条厚重的毯子一样覆盖在岩石上的样子。我认为这是那天发生的最令人惊奇的事情之一。我感到非常幸运，能够在那个时刻捕捉到正在发生的奇迹。我拥抱了负空间，捕捉到了一幅美丽、简约的图像。

底线：

适应能力强。变通。如果负空间在场景中占主导地位，那就顺其自然吧，即使您通常更喜欢避免简约的构图。合理？

2.用负空间来平衡正空间

摄影构图的一个关键目标是实现视觉平衡。您希望您的图像感觉完整、完整、令人满意。

实现平衡的一种方法是确定你的积极空间，然后用消极空间来对抗它。

例如，看下图。你可以看到积极的空间——握紧的拳头。这是一个强大、引人注目的主题，但它被周围所有的负空间所抵消。它创造了整体平衡，如您所见：

顺便说一句，重要的是要认识到大量的负空间可以平衡少量的正空间。积极的空间具有侵略性和力量。负空间更加柔和，甚至舒缓。因此，除非你特别想要一张非常引人注目的图像，否则积极的空间应该小剂量。

一些摄影师采用“2:1”负空间规则，即为每一部分正空间添加两部分负空间。我不喜欢以这种方式限制自己，但这是一个值得牢记的好准则。

3.尝试极简主义

正如我上面所解释的， 简约的构图利用负空间来产生巨大的效果。它们都是关于负空间的；它们占用大量的负空间，包括一点正空间，并创造出引人注目的结果。

这是一个极简主义图像的示例，其中阴影充当正空间，而砖块提供一些空的负空间：

如果你喜欢简约的外观，我强烈建议你尝试一下。实现起来非常简单。

以下是我的建议：

  1. 首先确定一个主要主题，例如一棵树、一个人或一座建筑物。这将是你的积极空间。
  2. 调整你的正片、焦距和相机角度，直到你的主要拍摄对象独自一人，周围只有负空间。 （低视角对此非常有用；通过下降到地面，您可以将拍摄对象置于天空中。）
  3. 消除尽可能多的颜色。如果可以的话，您想要均匀性：在高度和谐的场景中仅使用一种或两种颜色。
  4. 将主要拍摄对象放置在构图的边缘。您可以尝试将拍摄对象置于三分功率点或沿着网格线，但您也可以考虑将其移近画面边缘。

下面的树照片非常简约。它包括位于角落的一棵小树作为正空间，而照片的其余部分（大部分）是负空间，以实现良好的整体平衡。

4.利用负空间来传达情感

负空间往往是暗淡的，甚至是忧郁的，尤其是在黑白图像中。

利用这个事实。用你的作品讲述一个故事——一个充满悲伤、孤独或安静的快乐的故事。

当然，正如我上面强调的，你应该让场景引导你。但您也可以通过缩小或找到独特的空白背景等方式，小心地为构图添加更多负空间。

看看这张充满负空间的图像。是不是感慨万千？

是的，这是一个充满情感的镜头，至少在我看来是这样。空旷的天空，洒满了一点积极的空间，讲述着一个迷人的、令人难忘的故事。

5.仰望天空

在场景中找到大量负空间有时可能是一个挑战。但如果你觉得你的构图缺乏负空间，你可能只需要向上看。

天空通常具有平坦的外观，为负空间提供了绝佳的画布，它当然可以帮助将观看者的注意力吸引到您的主题上。换句话说，天空不会侵扰或分散注意力；它会影响人们的注意力。它就在那里，它可以有效地平衡你作品中的积极空间。

如何在镜头中加入更多的天空？尝试改变你的角度。低下来。将相机朝上。突然，天空成为你构图的主要部分，普通的快照变得更加有趣。

这种手法可以将拥挤、杂乱的街景变成平静、安详的画面，也可以使田野中的一朵花显得深邃而有意义。所以下次当你在负空间中挣扎时，记得看看天空。它始终在那里，等待帮助您创作完美的照片。

6.尝试黑白转换

您知道黑白色调可以改变您的图像吗？ It's true!黑白转换可以将视为正空间的内容转变为负空间。

您会看到，当您使用颜色时，某些区域具有多种色调，这通常确保它们显示为积极的空间。但剥去这些颜色，突然间，你会留下许多几乎相同的灰色——以及大量的负空间。

换句话说，通过将镜头转换为黑白，分散注意力的颜色就会消失。这可以将曾经混乱的区域变成宁静的负空间，为您的图像增添全新的优雅气息。

当然，这种技术并不是每次都有效。这取决于照片中现有的色调。但当它真正发挥作用时，结果可能是惊人的。极简主义的黑白图像充满负空间，具有难以抗拒的永恒吸引力。

7.消除干扰

想象一下，捕捉到一个完美的场景，后来却发现背景中有一个杂散的物体。

分心可能会毁掉一篇作品。它们将注意力从主题上转移开，使图像变得混乱，使观看者的眼睛感到困惑和徘徊。在负空间摄影中，这尤其有害。

你看，干扰总是会给图像增添积极的空间。它们打断了负空间旨在创造的主题的重点。无论您想要简约的图像还是平衡的构图，干扰都会让一切失去平衡。

在按下快门按钮之前，请花点时间扫描整个画面。寻找任何不属于的东西，并调整你的构图以将其排除。这可能意味着改变你的角度，重新定位你的相机，或者等待合适的时机。借助无干扰的框架，您将更有可能实现正负空间之间的完美和谐。

8. 走得更远

您是否曾感到被镜头束缚？

广角镜头开辟了一个充满可能性的新世界。它们扩展了您的视野，让您能够将充满负空间的广阔背景包含在内。想象一下这样的风景，有一棵孤独的树，背后是看似无尽的天空。或者想象田野里有几朵花，背后是一片永远延伸的草地。这就是广角视角所能捕捉到的。

但如果你没有广角镜头怎么办？ Don't worry;您仍然可以捕捉到相同的效果。只需后退几步，找到一个新的有利位置，然后从那里拍摄即可。这可能需要一些尝试和错误，但只要有耐心，您就会找到正确的位置。

无论是否广角，使用广角负空间都可以给你的照片带来一种宏伟和简约的感觉。它将强调主题，同时创造美妙的规模感。

9. 在 Instagram 上分享你的照片

分享你的作品是创作过程中有益的一部分，我认为 Instagram 是展示负空间摄影的绝佳平台。

为什么负空间在 Instagram 上效果这么好？

嗯，负空间的简单性吸引了观众的注意力。 Instagram 是一个通常在手机上查看的平台，当用户滚动浏览动态时会简短地显示图像。具有大量负空间的照片更容易处理，即使是不经意的观看者也会被缩略图大小的文件惊呆。

基本上，负空间增加了一种艺术感，在快节奏的社交媒体世界中脱颖而出。您的关注者会欣赏他们能够轻松理解并与图像建立联系。

并考虑使用迎合负空间和极简主义的特定主题标签。与欣赏这种风格的社区互动。您会对自己能够建立的联系和获得的反馈感到惊讶！

负空间摄影：最后的话

摄影是一个充满无限可能性的世界，而负空间是你的创意武器库中的一个强大工具。到目前为止，您应该对什么是负空间以及如何将其应用于各种摄影类型有深入的了解。

请记住，负空间不仅限于简约的镜头。这是一种引导观众注意力、创造和谐、甚至在图像中讲述更深层次故事的方式。无论您是要捕捉令人惊叹的风景、引人入胜的街景还是亲密的肖像，负空间都可能是一个微妙而深刻的探索元素。

Don't be afraid to share your work on platforms like Instagram, where your negative space photography can resonate with viewers. From landscapes to street photography, negative space has its place, and even in genres that focus more on positive space, there's room for experimentation.
